reviewText: I have previously owned an iPhone 4 and two Android smartphones, and this is my favorite cellphone yet. I generally like the interface updates, though there are annoyances to be found. First the good news. The iPhone 5 is thin and light, which I love. It's fast and Internet connectivity is generally quite good. The camera yields generally good photos, but mine has annoying shutter lag issues much like my iPhone 4 did; more distressing is that on mine the image that is presented onscreen is not the image actually captured. Depending on whether it is in a landscape or portrait format it cuts the top or the left side of the frame off. Imagine my extreme annoyance when I discovered that the majority of photos I took from the front row of a recent Joe Bonamassa concert lopped Joe's head off, but gave spectacular pictures of his shoes. (Joe's a snappy dresser, and they were very nice shoes.) This is such an annoyance I have thought of returning it for that alone, but I normally use a camera to take photographs, so I haven't yet. This doesn't seem to be a problem in video mode.Some improvements are not. The calendar is virtually impossible to sync with my AOL calendar (multiple trips to the Genius bar and reassurances that it's entirely compatible and they would fix it have ended up with nothing.) I'd just use a different calendar app, but I have a friend who is dedicated to the AOL calendar system, so this is a better solution for me for now (providing it ever works, anyway.) I also dislike the time zone functionality when entering items in my iPhone calendar. The phone clarity and signal strength aren't that great, honestly, and may be worse than my iPhone 4. I live with them, but am not a fan. Battery life is also not that good; I would much prefer a swappable battery, but Apple seems to think it knows better.Despite my relatively minor reservations (battery life and camera problems are my biggest concerns) I still like this phone. It's light, it's fast, it's powerful, and it's still a good choice. If I had to do it over again I'd get the 64GB version to have more onboard video memory, but careful allocation of TV programs lets 32GB work adequately for me. Having used this phone for a few months now I feel confident using it and recommend it to people who like the Apple IOS.

reviewText: My headline pretty much sums up my review.  This IS a great phone. Don't get me wrong.  The 2-star rating isn't because it's a bad phone.  It's because Apple basically did nothing to upgrade the 4S other than making it a pubic hair faster and re-designing it a bit to be slightly longer and lighter.  That's it.  The 4S is a great phone, the iPhone 5 is also great, but maybe, what, 2% better than the 4S? It's not worth it to upgrade, unless you have an iPhone 3 or something.Apple is a multi-billion dollar corporation for a reason.  They're brilliant.  They could have EASILY have given us tons of additional features that they have in their arsenal, but decided that enough people would buy the iPhone 5, based on the new design alone.  The major hardware upgrades will come with the 5S next year, when we'll see a 12 megapixel camera, and various other big-time upgrades.  And guess what?  People who bought the 5 will immediately buy the 5S, because this one will actually have "must have" features.  Apple's marketing and the way they mind-F their customers is absolutely brilliant.  I'm not saying it's a bad thing -- it's genius.If you have a 4S, you're a sucker for getting the 5, bottom line.  Shame on you if you already did.  Thankfully, my wife got the 5 (upgraded from a 3, that was literally falling apart), so I have had plenty of time to play around with it and form an opinion.  I will be keeping my 4S until the 5S comes out, probably this upcoming fall, and I'm sure the 5S will be revolutionary.

reviewText: Hi there, this is a review from a 22 year old tech enthusiast. The review is quite long, but I have organized them into separate categories, so you don't have to read the whole thing. Here's a little about myself.I am a computer science major, and have always been an Android fan. I've owned:-Nexus 4-Galaxy Nexus-Samsung Galaxy s2-Samsung Note-HTC Amaze-HTC Sensation-HTC Radar-HTC 8x-Many other older modelsNeedless to say, I have had a lot of experience of all three mobile OSes. I am very enthusiastic about tech, always swapping phones, always looking for that perfect phone. I own a macbook air and a custom built gaming desktop PC.Why I chose the iPhone over the HTC One and S4:I am under my stepdad's family plan, so when it was time to upgrade, I had to choose between the HTC One, S4, and iPhone 5. I always thought I would choose the HTC One when it first came out. However, I chose the iPhone 5 mainly because I wanted something new to try. I know that the HTC One and s4 are both great options, but they did not feel like a significant upgrade from a Nexus 4 (which I love). In fact, they seemed slower than the Nexus 4 in everyday tasks (most likely from fragmentation from HTC/Samsung overlays AND carrier apps). The HTC One has much better hardware than the Nexus 4, but there is a definitely lag in the OS due to the fragmentation. Samsung S4 does a much better job with their software, but I hate their plastic feel. IMHO, I like the overall package that the Nexus 4 gives you, which is high quality in both software and hardware. So because I felt my Nexus 4 is better than both the One and S4, I decided to try out the iPhone 5.What I think of Android:I absolutely love the Nexus 4 and the Galaxy Nexus, but I HATE every other Android phones. The fragmentation just makes the entire experience a chore. I spent so much time installing custom mods. Most of the phones had major shortcomings (no/late updates, battery life, intense lag, etc). To fix the software shortcomings, you would have to know how to mod, then research the best mods for you specific phone model, and update the mods when the "cook" for the mod release a new version. Furthermore, the mods you install would oftentimes have bugs of it's own. It just seems in order to enjoy non-Nexus android phones, you have to be willing to spend the time on the phone. To me, that's bull****. I don't want to spend time on a phone, I have other stuff to do. A phone should make your life simpler, not the other way around. Don't get me wrong, I absolutely love the Nexus 4, the only shortcoming I see it having is it doesn't have LTE and the glass back cracks easily. I'm not bashing on android, in fact there are a lot of things in android that I love which I can't do in iOS (torrents and file management to name a couple). Android also syncs well with both PC and Mac because of the file management system, and that most of its information is stored in the cloud. But the main idea here is that Android is cluttered with too many information and overlay skins (except for the Nexus phones), major drawbacks (whether it be software or hardware), and complicated. Nexus phones on the other hand, ha great hardware and software. No overlay skins or carrier apps, just pure android. Simple. If you like android, get a Nexus device.What I think of Windows Phone 8:Two words. Too young. The apps are noticeable worse than the Android and iOS counterparts. The Youtube app was downright frustrating to use. I think Microsoft is going in the right direction, giving the PC and phone a similar feel and integrating them together, but as of right now, they are still behind the curve. It syncs well with Windows 8 PC, so it is simple to use, but the apps right now are simply trash. Windows Phone feels more like iOS than android because they made it very simple to use and also limiting.What I think of iOS:Simplicity. Sometimes a little too simple (simple wifi toggles are impossible, will change in iOS 7). To an advanced user like me, it also feels constricted. I can't just drag a movie file into the iphone, I have to convert the movie file into a file that iTunes accept, then sync iTunes with iPhone. However, I do think iTunes is a pro because it is kind of like the command center of your iOS devices, where everything is located in one location, something I wish Google will work on. iOS is also very fluid. It is noticeable more fluid than the HTC One and S4, but less so with the Nexus 4. But mainly, the feeling you get with iOS is simplicity. For example, let's look at the camera app. It doesn't give you as many options as the HTC One camera app, but that's just how I like it. The options the iPhone camera let you change are the options I actually understand, I have no idea most of what the HTC One camera option even do. This can relate to almost everything on iOS. It doesn't give you a lot of options, which equates to less clutter. The options they give you are options you understand and actually use. Simple simple simple. iOS also syncs very well with other Apple products, and decently well with Windows PC through iTunes.iPhone 5 vs Nexus 4 (HARDWARE only):I'll be comparing the iPhone 5 to my favorite phone of all time (yes even more than the HTC One as explained above), Nexus 4. The iPhone have a better quality screen, better camera, better speakers, better built quality, slightly better battery life, LTE support, better call quality (3 mikes), physical camera button (volume up). The Nexus 4 have better grips, smoother touchscreen (slippery), bigger screen, faster processor and more RAM (though that doesn't matter in real life), smaller bezel. The screen is smaller on the iPhone, which many see as a con, but I know that my girlfriend actually prefers a smaller screen because she likes smaller phones (more pocketable...her words). I also enjoy having a change of pace with the smaller display, I can actually operate the phone with one hand, and it's a lot less noticeable in my pocket. In general, the iPhone 5 is better hardware-wise.iPhone 5 vs Nexus 4 (SOFTWARE only):A lot of the shortcomings for Android phones are not on the Nexus 4. The Nexus 4 is always updated with the latest software from Google, and it's super fluid. It doesn't have any HTC/Samsung/Motorola overlays, or carrier-forced apps. Most importantly, pure android feels simple. Something Google needs to work on is something similar to iTunes, a central program that keeps all the data of your phone and organizes them in a computer. I also absolutely LOVE the software "back, home, menu" buttons. This is absolutely genius when the first introduced it on the Galaxy Nexus. This allows the phone to give you a wider screen real-estate when you watch videos, and allowing the phone to have a smaller bezel. iOS on the other hand feels even simpler, sometimes to a fault. Like I said earlier, transferring movies onto the iPhone seems like a chore, but it does stay in the iTunes library for the future, so it's not too bad. Apple's multitasking can be oftentimes more limiting than android, but it does save battery life. I am a very big supporter of Apple's hardware and software optimization. Apple makes most of their hardware and all of their software, and they do it in a way that makes them work so well together. The iphone 5's power is probably half as powerful as the Nexus 4 spec-wise, but it runs as fluid if not more fluid than the Nexus 4. Siri versus Google Now is also something to compare, but to me they are both great options (much better than s-voice at least). Overall, android on the Nexus 4 has a slight advantage over iOS in my opinion, but iOS is more simpler and organized.  This really depends on personal preference.iPhone 5 Impressions:After using the phone for about a week, I have not had any major issues or see any major drawbacks. The phone is simple and problem free. This is in no way of saying the iPhone is perfect, it's far from it. With my previous phones (excluding Nexus 4), I've always found major drawbacks that I simply can't live with, which explains why I switched phones so many times until I got the Nexus 4, which I've stayed with for the longest. The iPhone provides fantastic and beautiful hardware, optimized and simple software, and wraps them up together into a great experience. I also know that they will keep me updated with the latest softwares, unlike non-Nexus android phones. The limitations on iOS does give me some issues as an advanced user, BUT honestly, it doesn't bother me that much, simply because I don't do many advanced things on my phone anyways. The screen is a change of pace to me also, but I do enjoy using the phone in one hand, it's a much better fit. To me, Apple gives me the impression that it doesn't do anything perfectly, but it does do everything very very well.Conclusion:Do I recommend the iPhone 5? Well, how much money do you have? If money is not an issue, go for it. If money is an issue, buy the Nexus 4. Both phones will give you a great experience. Buy the HTC One or S4 if you absolutely want a 1080p display and LTE and hate the limitations of iOS, but just know their software updates are usually months late, and sometimes will never come, and you will have a very cluttered experience. Don't buy a Windows 8 phone unless you have a very specific reason to do so.I know of the Android vs iOS flame war that goes on even today, but it really boils down to personal preference. I've been on the Android ship for a long time, because Android allows me to do more stuff on my phone. But now that I've used so many different phones, I realize I don't use my phone to do anything advanced, I save that stuff for my computer. I realize I need a phone that doesn't need me to provide maintenance and troubleshoot. I need a phone that simplifies my life. I need a phone that does everything well. Both the iPhone 5 and Nexus 4 does it. Simplicity sells, and that is one thing that Apple and Google understands. Samsung and HTC has much to learn.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------UPDATE:After using the iPhone for a little longer, I can say that there are some gripes I have against it, but also some positives.CONS:-Most of my complaints stems from the lack of file management. For example I can't download a file from my email, only view it.-I miss swype-Watching videos on a 4-inch screen does seem constricting at first, but I got used to it.-When using android, there usually is always a setting I can find that would solve whatever that's bothering me, whether it's an android setting or app setting. On iOS, many times I can't find those settings.-Android notifications seem better.PROS:-I thought my Nexus 4 had a beautiful screen, but after using the iPhone 5 and going back to the Nexus 4 to try it out, I find the Nexus 4's color washed out and inaccurate. The iPhone 5 has a gorgeous screen. Nexus 4 also seems super fat now lol.-iTunes keeps me organized, and also backs my iPhone's data up. Nice to see coming from android.-The size of the iPhone really does feel great in one hand. Most of the 4.7"+ android phones feel constricting simply because you need both your hands free to do most tasks, especially on the Galaxy Notes.-The "reader" feature on Safari is fantastic-The "do not disturb" feature is more useful than I thought.-Once again, the iPhone reiterates to me that it doesn't do anything perfectly, but it does everything well.ADDITIONAL THOUGHTS:Google just added the HTC One and S4 Google Edition phones on their Play Store. To summarize, both are running pure android, thus I think they're better. HOWEVER, because Google wasn't the one who made the hardware for these phones, the pure android software isn't optimized on the phones yet. For example, most tasks seem faster on the skinned version of the phones. The IR Blaster on the HTC One also doesn't work as of right now. Small things like this makes me hesitant to pay $600 for them right now. I rather wait for the next Nexus device.

reviewText: I ordered this item expecting a good replacement for my iPhone 4 (Verizon) and it came with in the time expected but when I went to install the back glass the item wouldn't slide down like the OEM did and I sized it up with the original and it was too big... And on top of that, the seller will not refund more than 20% of my money... DO NOT BUY THIS ITEM OR FROM THIS SELLER! I replace iPhone parts for a part time job and this is by far the crappiest part I've ever received.
title: iPhone 4 for Verizon White Glass Replacement Back Cover

reviewText: While this product does not claim to be OEM, there are some very slight differences between the two. All in all it's nothing big enough for the average person to notice and I was impressed with the over all quality (one issue aside). For my purposes this was almost perfect. Make sure you remove the lens plastic before installation, it is located on the under side.Installation was a breeze, take off the screws (If you have the silly star pattern, do yourself a favor and but the right tool) slide it up, put the new glass on and slide it down. Towards the end of installation I discovered only one of the set screw mounts was properly threaded. The left side (if the phone is laying, face up) seemed to be over bored. I can see it is threaded, but the standard Iphone screws are too thin and slide right past the threads. I tried this with several different iPhone screws and they all slide past the threads. I also checked to make sure all these screws to work with the right side mount, and the OEM mounts.This was the ONLY problem, and not a huge deal for me. Those screws are there to prevent the back from sliding up and fall off. I always use a case anyhow and with one screw securely in place the back glass wont be going anywhere. If you plan on using your phone without a case this may be something to consider.
title: iPhone 4 for Verizon White Glass Replacement Back Cover

reviewText: Fit was a little off, but nothing that broke the deal. I appreciated that it came with the necessary tools for install. I will say it's just as fragile as the original as it shatters just the same. I guess that's just the risk you take when having a glass phone.

reviewText: I have been using my iPhone 4S for about 6 months now and I love the phone. I was a heavy Blackberry user in the past but as everyone knows that company has gone downhill. At that point, I made a conscious decision to switch phones and I had to decide between Android, Apple, or a Windows based system. I use a Windows laptop at home so I thought I would go with an Android or Windows phone. I tried many Android and Windows phones but did not like the user interface. The Android phones seemed so fragmented in that there was no standard; every phone manufacturer has their own version of customized Android. For me I like things simple. I next tried a Windows phone but that was the slowest phone I had ever used. I'm not sure how Metro will be but hopefully they fix a lot of those issues. I finally tried the iPhone and fell in love with the ease and simplicity of the phone. I really like iOS and how simple it is to operate. I do have to say that I would not have gone with the iPhone if it could not sync with Outlook but luckily Apple built an Outlook plugin which works very well.In terms of the phone itself, the screen is beautiful and the 8 mg pixel camera is great. The phone is quite fast running any type of app and battery life is pretty good. I thought that I would never get used to the touchscreen keyboard rather than the Blackberry physical keyboard but it is actually quite easy when you turn the phone horizontal. The accuracy is still much better on the Blackberry but you get used to the touchscreen pretty quickly! Overall, this is the best phone that I have ever used!
title: Apple iPhone 4S 16GB - AT&T -

reviewText: I recently got this version as a refurb and locked to AT&T.;I'm using it on Straight Talk prepaid service, which pretty much is half the monthly cost than most postpaid carriers (AT&T; and verizon).The phone is great.  I've been using BB's since 2005, and then early this year, I made switch to the 3gs.  That phone was ok, but was it slow and painful.  It really made me miss my blackberry's speed and composure.However, this 4s is super fast.  While my typing will not rival my speed on BB, its very close.  Luckily I don't compose that many emails or txts anymore, so I prefer that the 4s can do more intensive internet tasks with minimum of effort.If you are on BB or iPhone 3gs, you really need to upgrade to the iPhone 4s to see what you are missing.  The phone is sturdy (I dropped it the 2nd day on concrete sidewalk on there were the minimum of scratches on the side), though, I don't think it will handle multiple drops and survive like a BB does.  Everything else on this phone is great, fast and fun to use.
title: Apple iPhone 4S 16GB - AT&T -

reviewerName: Jaffrey W. Ali "Relentless Pursuit of Technology"
reviewText: While I have owned an iPhone 4S for around a year now, the purpose of my review is for someone who may be considering the iPhone 4S as a current buy. Getting straight to the pros and cons of the iPhone:1. Extremely well balanced feature set that makes it ideal for everyday use. The redesigned antenna works very well even in low signal areas, the music player, the web browser, the email client, the App Store, the camera and battery life are all best in class in my opinion.2. Out of the Apple services, the Maps app has a very good UI and is good for turn by turn navigation but the points of interest database isn't as good as Google - BUT you can always use Google Maps over the browser if you like so that is NOT a limitation in my opinion, AirPlay is very useful if you also have an Apple TV at home, iMessage and FaceTime are not unique in that other platforms have similar inbuilt apps, but the iPhone 4S implementation is simply better because the UI is much more straightforward and it never ever locks up the device or causes it to crash.3. Siri works very well for voice commands and has gotten much better of late. iCloud is also another well executed service if you want to store music and movies in the cloud and then access it from any Apple device. The iPhone 4S integration with iCloud is very good and with it, you don't need to ever connect an iPhone 4S to a computer. I have never connected mine to a PC in a year.4. The screen is very clear and is easily visible even in direct sunlight - even at max brightness the iPhone 4S has more than acceptable battery life. All the other large screen phones I have used, at max brightness the battery life start declining at very fast rate. In a nutshell, with the iPhone 4S one is not compromising acceptable battery life for screen brightness.5. While some may find the Apple UI boring, the advantage is that the UI is not intrusive and let's a user focus squarely on using apps and not on fiddling with features and functions on the device.6. The size is smaller than the typical Android phone, but the iphone 4S has a very good overall feel and for my daily use it is very convenient. I guess if you play a lot of games then a larger screen may be acceptable, but as a daily smartphone the iPhone 4S is extremely well designed aesthetically and in size. The iphone 4S is completely one hand operational without any issues whatsoever. The phone is also very well balanced to hold.7. The glass back is likely to break and that is probably the biggest drawback of the iPhone 4/S design. If you are someone who drops their phone then you simply have to get a bumper, with the bumper the phone is pretty much shatter proof. I have dropped mine with a bumper several times and the phone is still scratch free.In my opinion, the iPhone 4S is a true classic. It will easily meet the needs of most people who use smartphones. It is extremely well balanced with features and design. I didn't really mention games as a strong point, but the Apple App Store easily has the most compelling games available for a smartphone even if the screen is smaller on the iPhone. In the end the difference in screen size between the iPhone 4S and iPhone 5 is only half an inch and between an iPhone 4S and the larger Android phones it's only an inch or so. In terms usability, the extra screen real estate does not matter much especially since the UI on the 4S is so smooth and responsive and zooming in and out is not an issue. It is much worse when you have a larger screen but the phone's UI stutters and apps crash and you need to remove the battery every now and then to reboot it.The iPhone 4S is one of the best consumer electronics products I have ever owned. It is so well executed that I believe it will be considered a classic. The 4S is a much better phone than the 4 and justifies the upgrade, but in my humble opinion the jump from 4S to 5 is much more subtle in terms of what more the phone can do.
title: Apple iPhone 4S 16GB - AT&T -

reviewText: Same old locked down ecosystem and OS.  I owned every iphone since the original and I finally had enough and sold my 4s and got a Galaxy Nexus.  The first 3 iphones were ahead of the crowd.  But over the last few years iphone has gotten stale while the rest of the industry is innovating and is now way ahead.
title: Apple iPhone 4S 16GB - AT&T -

reviewText: This phone is amazing! I'm always finding new features about this phone. It's very user friendly and intuitive and I had no problems getting used to the phone right out of the box. It's a great entertainment center and toy all rolled into one and oh yah, a great phone (haha). If you're debating between this and an Android phone, do your research and see which one suits your personality/taste more.
title: Apple iPhone 4S 16GB - AT&T -

reviewText: I wonder if I am the only person on the face of the earth that does not like the Iphone 4S. Call me an old curmudgeon, but I just call them like I see them. I got the phone when it first came out, so have had it for some time.Bottom line is that it is not a very good telephone. The number one reason I have a telephone is to make telephone calls, and I would like that part of it to work exceptionally, and it does not. Here are my list of concerns.1) Dropped/Missed calls- I live very near an AT&T; tower, and have a clear line of sight to the tower, but rarely have more than one bar at my house. The phone does not ring when someone calls me, but informs me later that I have had a missed call. Similarly, it regularly drops my calls, or gives me a "no service" error message.2) Poor Battery Life- I would expect a cell phone to get me through the day on a full charge. I do not mind charging the phone every night, but I want it to get me through the day. I have found that you can not depend on this phone to make it through the day. Even doing things like turning the bluetooth off and all that does not get me to the point that I can even moderately use it and not have the battery dead before I get home.3) Poor sound quality- When on the phone, I do not get crystal clear voice quality.4) Jams up - Phone jams on me every couple of weeks and I have to reset it. In particular, the skype ap appears to cause the phone problems.This phone was designed to do it all . . . it just does not do it very well.
title: Apple iPhone 4S 16GB - AT&T -

reviewText: I bought the 4s a while back when it just came out, so I've had it for a while. Prior smart phone was the Galaxy S, which wasn't bad either until a few months in when the thing bogged down.The 4s has been pretty stable, especially prior to the IOS 6 install. Ever since the last update I've noticed some delays or hick-ups that are only solvable by rebooting the device. Overall it's a solid device for which you don't need a screen protector. The glass is scratch resistant and mine still looks like new.Facetime is great, iMessages are awesome, especially since some of my relatives live overseas.If you're wanting an iPhone, start with this one, it's the same as the 5 only a smaller screen and much cheaper now. Don't think you can personalize the phone completely to your liking, because after all, it is an Apple.
title: Apple iPhone 4S 16GB - AT&T -

reviewText: I was on the fence between the 5C and 5S and I went for the 5C. The reason was because of the color and because I am a little hard on phones so I felt the build was more rugged.The 5C is not selling well and it is certainly not a cheap phone. I know the S model has a little bit more power on the camera and the different chip but the 5C meets my needs well.  Note - there are some packages on Cydia that you can download to give it the same functionality as the 5S. I'm on T-Mobile and Internet on LTE is blazingly fast, video calling works great and email and calendars are top notch. I was using a 3GS for a few years as a backup phone to my BlackBerry and now the BB is the backup. If you JB your phone, you can do a lot with it.Note - I did get a bad phone first time around - the phone and charger were way hot. Since I bought it locally I was able to exchange it within 14 days and got a new one and all is well.I am surprised at some of the bad reviews but it looks like it has to do with the sellers.PS I ordered white not blueIf you are in the US and are going to pay full price for the phone, go to Apple or your local carrier.

reviewText: I am alway sone model behind because I'm conservative.  I had a 3 GS and moved up to accommodate a special app for my truck.  Glad I did.  Real long battery life, IOS7 (which has updated 3 times for bugs) and a larger screen.  My only complaint about larger screens is its harder to apply screen savers.  I used to use ANdroid burt my phone frequently rebooted and Android phones limit the number of software upgrades to entice you to buy a new phone.  Apple provided full software upgrades to my 3GS until 7 came out.  As far as regular conversation goes I don't see a lot of difference between Apple and the better androids.  Many more apps for android, but a lot of them duplicate functions.  The 2 apps I miss most are the SWYPE keyboard and a YouTube downloader.  I found away around the YouTube issue but not the keyboard.  Why Apple refuses to put a row of numbers at the top of the keypad like a real keyboard is beyond me.  Overall I find the IOS platform more stable but more expensive and no difference in voice quality.
title: Apple iPhone 5c, White 16GB (Unlocked)

reviewText: I have a certain part of my life always switched phones. Doesn't matter what phone I have, seems I'm never happy with them after about a year. I decided to leave my DROID RAZR and give the iPhone 5C a chance. My first black/white unit ended up water damaged, and that led me back to Android. The phone I chose was an S4 and it was HORRIBLE. I can't not recommend that phone enough.Anyway, I found a good deal on another white 5C 32GB and decided I should buy it. I am pleasantly surprised with the phone. Very loud speakers, SIRI is awesome as always. I thought at first the charging port would inconvenience me, having all of the same hookups, but ALL i needed was a lightning port converter and I was back in business the way I was working originally. With my job-site radio I can use the auxiliary hook up and all works well.There are two things that irk me to no end about this phone and I cannot stress them enough, that said, I feel that would bring the phones rating down if I impacted such the score on the overall rating.My problems are this: Apple doesn't allow you to set songs as ringtones, YES, there are a couple of applications that do just that out there, but they involve you using different software and different things on Itunes, wish it was as easy as it was on the Android phones.The second problem is the camera has been somewhat iffy since day one. My 5C was still in warranty (the new one) so I did swap the phone and have also restored it once, the pictures just either look dark or cloudy. I've done EVERYTHING that Apple has said, and still come up on same problem. I've just had it on this phone, and I've owned a 2G, 3G, 4 and 4S before this.However for the 16Gb and the starting price of 99$, you can't pass on that deal. You are getting a great phone for a great price. I had to order a 32G because I have way too many pictures and apps, but that phone was the price of the standard 5S 16G. This phone works as well, who cares its plastic on the back it won't break as much as the other iPhone's do, and you can get a case and it won't annoy you.There will always be a "bagger" of a certain item, but I think you can trust someone who works in the mobile phone industry fixing and selling phones. I really like this phone and I think Apple is on the right track. Same speed as my exes 5S phone. I just think a lot of people think, wow, it's made of plastic, I don't want to deal with a plastic phone, but you need to realize, it's the same phone and comes in different colors. I think it's better than the 5S personally.Another thing I wanted to also say is that cases weren't readily available when this first launched. However, this was remedied in recent months by manufacturers of cases such as INCASE and Incipio stepping up and making functional cases everyone loves!If you are on a tight budget, or just want a nice phone in a cool color, choose this. You won't regret it, I know that  much

reviewText: ETA 5/11/2014:  Apple is now committed to pushing this into their affordable category.  The $99 deals abound not just for mother's day and store employees have been given this device in exchange for the last lowest commonn demoninator model - the ipod touch.***This phone is not as audible as the 4 for an unknown reason - it has to be on its maximum volume level and even then words are missed and you have to ask the caller to repeat themselves.The White/Silver version looks VERY Korean.  It's not slick and sophisticated in my opinion.  It evokes the spirit of a Samsung smartphone in white that has been shrunk down.  If this were the Iphone6, I would be much happier since a Samsung Galaxy Note 3 order was cancelled to get this phone but we felt we really needed an updated smartphone.  Hopefully, Apple devices will retain their resalability.We have laptops and rokus using wifi with no problem but the touch 4g always buffered after a few minutes and you would think that this latest and greatest would have as decent wifi as a $35 Roku LT but that is not the case.  Since I am not an Apple addict, I would return this phone and never touch another Apple device but I am not primary user of this brand's products so I try to do as much research as I can stomach to cushion the expected frustrations of signing on to own and participate in this artificial reality.The sensor issues seem to be due to a new supplier, Bosch, and that means ALL the new phones are affected and Apple is not known for doing a product recall.  The sensors are off by DIFFERENT degrees so it is not believable that any firmware or app will be able to offset the sensor - at best, they will embed software that will throw the sensors off in the opposite direction to minimize the amount it is off level.  SO LAME. I haven't pulled out a carpenter's level yet to test it but the ongoing revelations including a teardown of the phone indicate that Bosch screwed up and all 5s and 5c owners will be stuck with this because Apple never fixed antennagate on the iPhone 4.  They certainly never contacted owners of the 4 to offer them a free case as their idea of a "fix" for the antenna problem.It takes forever for the fingerprint sensor to identify your fingerprint so get comfortable before you press your finger on it because you can't lift it up until Apple is finished.SIRI is a toy - an elaborate Magic 8 Ball with more responses tuned in.  It is easier to voicedial on a dumbphone than to use Siri's primary purpose in life because ultimately, Siri is NOT AT ALL intelligent.  What Siri does do if you play around long enough to realize is RECORD YOUR VOICE and then repeat what you said in Siri's voice which means their software coded your voice and translated into Siri's voice - it does NOT mean that Susan Bennett happened to record the same words that you just spoke to Siri.  That in addition to the fingerprint sensor and the cameras mean this device can COPY you.Still, we are okay with upgrading to this phone.  There simply were too many things after two years that the Iphone 4 could not do like iBook.  We never updated the iOS 4 sparing us battery issues like the ones for the Touch 4G so this is how we think the Apple devices work - when you can afford to upgrade, pick the latest model even if an older version is free so you don't get locked out of new features like "autofocus" that only works with the 5s camera.Don't sell your old iphone for ninety bucks or whatever.  Keep it and don't order product protection so if the new phone gets destroyed or stolen before the two years are up, you have a cheaper backup than the monthly protection plan.When the next iphone after your version is iminent, upgrade your iOS and then never upgrade it again to spare yourself all the coincidental problems that make you want to upgrade to the latest and greatest that don't suffer all these handicaps after ugprading to the new iOS.Scour the repetitive articles and then turn off all the settings that drain the battery like auto app refresh.KNOW that Apple does not do product recalls and be careful with overcharging your nonremovable battery.  If not for Android updating and malware issues, we would have broken from Buying American (Chinese suicides) for the Samsung Galaxy Note 3.  Ultimately, we just didn't want to do too much work with a smartphone so we are still with Apple.  Apple customer service is not that great, not at all generous but if we have to have a smartphone which is driven by the media to be a keeping up with the Jones, it is better to be with the operating system that seems favored by app developers and yes, there is a cultural comfort level with dealing with an American brand.After our problems with the touch 64gb and Apple customer service being no help with the battery issue, we are loathe to max out storage for any Apple device with nonremovable memory and battery but 16gb fills up pretty easily so we are going with 32 gb.  The Iphone has not sold me on Mac computers which I have never owned and I think are overpriced and some kind of IDEA of computing that is not value for money though it may look and be easy to use.  As smartphones go however, Android is an unpreposessing name and so are their iterations especially "jellybean" - very offputting.  The fact that even if you don't mind not getting a timely OS update may still kill the apps you do have and that malware is an issue with the apps forcing some phones to get bricked is why we are not indulging in the tempting Samsung offerings.We don't trust Apple because of what we learned from the touch 4g battery issues but we don't trust nonApple brands more as a result of not trusting Apple.The issues with Gmail privacy have certainly cast suspicion on the integrity of what Google does including their Android OS.  Whatever happened to not being evil?If Microsoft had the breadth of apps and media products for sale (Android doesn't have the scope of the iTunes store) then I would consider a Windows phone but browsing the Android app store - no South Park episodes! - made me cancel the order for the Samsung Galaxy Note 3.  Hopefully, the resale market for Apple will still be healthy then - another difference from Android phones.CASE of choice:Tylt Energi Power Case for iPhone 5/5S - Retail Packaging - Black/Graywhich is subtly shaped in a charming way and feels MUCH better than the rubbery grippy silicone cases so even if it did not provide the extended battery, I would still use this case BUT the lightning cables are no longer needed as it has a provided micro usb cable.CASES THAT BLOW:SPIGEN SGP SGP10088 Slim Armor Case for iPhone 5/5S - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - Metal Slatehas a too low ridge around the front offering little if any protection and it was too thick to allow the lightning cable from monster to charge the phone.  I am using the provided screen protector however.The very expensiveLifeproof iPhone 5 Case - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - White And Graycovers the fingerprint sensor but shows the back of the phone so everyone know which color you got and they are coming out with a case for the 5s BUT I got the feeling it was scratching the sides of the phone when I tested it out.If Buying American, Choosing Apple versus Google's Motorola, REMEMBERThe Pacificand know that if Apple falls, so might these suppliers:Japanese electronics makers appear incapable of making the world-winning products that they made a generation ago. Even credit agencies are not optimistic about their prospects. Sony's credit rating? Junk. Sharp? Junk. Panasonic? Junk.Research by Morikawa and Goto shows how in 2012 Japan's electronics giants were using Apple as a life support system.Some of the figures are staggering.At Sharp's Kameyama No. 1 factory near Osaka, 100 percent of liquid-crystal display panels were devoted to Apple. Of the camera sensors from Sony's Kumamoto factory, 50 percent were for the US company's devices. Half of the DRAM production at Elpida's Hiroshima factory: for Apple.

reviewText: After years of prodding from friends ("What? A techie like you doesn't have an iPhone???") I finally broke down and bought one- the top of the line, with all the bells and whistles, and the maximum memory. It's a bit of a hit to the pocketbook, but I thought the payoff would be in portability and the computing power. And for the most part, I've been pleased with it. I love how it shares data with my iMac and iPad. But I do have some issues.It's certainly amazing how Apple has managed to cram all that computing power and battery life into such a tiny package, but they've done so at the expense of ruggedness and battery life. The first purchase I made for mine was an Otterbox Defender, and the second, an auxiliary battery and a second charging cord for in-car use. The case, because I can just see dropping this wand watching $849 turn into several ounces of inert plastic, glass and silicon, and the cord and battery because compared to the cell phones I've been using, this phone is a real power hog. While it gets a lot of oohs and aaahs for its tiny packaging, it would be nice if they made it a bit thicker and doubled the battery capacity. It would be even nicer if they made a ruggedized version with extended battery life; I'm thinking of spending another $99 and buying a Morphie case with a built-in battery.I would have also like to see Apple provide better tools for importing data from an older technology cell phone. The use of the nano-SIM means that this was the first phone I has where I couldn't simply slide the card out of one phone and into the next. It also means that I can't quickly switch to a back-up phone if this one suffers a failure and needs repair or replacement.So yes, an impressive phone and impressive technology. But not quite as practical as I'd hoped.Two week Update:As the novelty has work off, and I'm no longer checking it every few minutes just because of the novelty of it all, I find that the battery life is much better than I'd thought as first. But I'm still keeping a charger at bedside, a charging cord in my car, and a small back-up battery in my parka. I'm also finding more useful apps for it- even after having used an iPod Touch and an iPad for years. In fact, I'm starting to realize tha Apple has now successfully locked me into the iPhone.... forever. Sneaky, Apple. Very sneaky.

reviewText: The iPhone 5s is a pretty amazing phone and I would get the next version, when it comes out, if it weren't for the following MAJOR problem:APPLE has programmed the iOS so that all messages, inbound and outbound, including attachments, are saved on the phone with absolutely no option, within the OS, to delete them.Sure, they let the user THINK they have deleted the messages and attachments, but a quick dive into the phone's list of memory hogs shows that the MESSAGES app is taking up more and more space every day.If you enjoy sending and receiving pictures and videos via message, every time you do, it deletes from your available memory with no option, within the OS, to recover the memory that was just used.Now some people, in the conspiracy world, may think that this is a way for your personal messages to be recovered or spied on.... But I think the reason is more insidious. They don't care about your messages. They care if you buy another phone and buy one sooner and buy one with MORE memory because they cost MORE. And, yes, that new, more-memory, more expensive I-phone is going to experience the same memory choking end.Yes, I have confirmed that Apple is aware and has been aware of this "problem" and that they have been aware of it through the release of one iOS after another. Considering the logical ease of programming the ability to actually delete a file and recover memory, (we do it all of the time when we take photos off the phone) it's a logical conclusion that APPLE wants this included in the design of the phone.It's highway Robery It's unethical. It's grounds for a class-action lawsuit.And it's why I would never buy another one.Extra note about the 5s: (and APPLE is also aware if this one... And has no plans to fix it.): the power button is seated in such a way that it rattles. It may not sound like a big deal when you first hear it. It's a light tapping. But, the way the button is designed, pill shaped and curved on each end, when you are taking a video, the button teeters within the case portal and rattles. To the ear, it sounds like nothing. On the video it sounds like garbage cans being hammered on.Apple's response is that "it is not a defect. It is a "feature". It was designed for those people who accidentally dunk their phone in soda or coffee. If they do, this special metal button won't stick"I've actually talked to a few APPLE "geniuses" who read this prepared response to me. Ingenious! Call a defect a "feature" and avoid a recall.So, there is my sincere review of the iPhone 5s.I cannot suggest a different phone because I have no idea if the other companies are resorting to the same nasty tactic. If I learn more, I will update this post.
title: Apple iPhone 5s, Space Gray 16GB (Unlocked)

reviewText: In the past 4 years I have owned Android and (the now virtually redundant) Blackberry phones prior to buying an iPhone 5s in early December 2013. Overall I prefer the iPhone over the others and would recommend it, with a few minor reservations.The iPhone 5s is superior in these areas:1. The design is a work of art, finely sculpted and proportioned; a pleasure to hold and use2. The screen is fantastic; big enough to be really useful but small enough for the phone to be easily pocketable. The Blackberry screen was maybe too small for most applications except for email, and the Android too big and heavy for portable use. I particularly like the long narrow screen on the 5s3. A lot of thought has gone into the way a user can navigate around the screen through the different functions. I have owned an iPod Touch for a couple of years and have become a fan of Apple's clear and simple graphics: on the 5s, it's even better. The software never crashes, which it did with both my Android phones frequently4. For a user with larger than average hands/fingers, the on-screen keypad of the 5s is really well designed - especially true if you use the phone in landscape format which has the effect of widening the keypad. In comparison, the Android was frustrating and not very user-friendly and the Blackberry Storm completely hopeless - though the permanent keypad on the Curve was great5. The ring tone & speaker volume is louder and clearer on the iPhone than any of its rivals6. Phone reception is the best. I don't know how Apple manage this, but I have made and received calls in locations where other phones don't seem to work  - like travelling on the London underground and in deep underground car parks7. The camera is so good it's up to the standard of a dedicated Canon or Nikon compact, for the first time on a cellphone8. The memory (64GB) is vast, with a storage capacity so huge you're never likely to need more no matter what you download and store on it9. Siri, iMessage and Facetime are genuinely useful apps, not just gimmicks. They actually work well. The fingerprint scanner works too, though how much of a real security feature this is remains doubtfulGripes: very few -1. The battery life isn't great, but no worse than the Android Galaxy 4 and you can substantially improve it on the 5s by turning off power-hungry applications2. The unique nano-SIM means you can't swap the SIM over to another phone in an emergency, or for example if the phone is damaged and needs repair3. The price of the 5s is a bit steep, but here you really do get what you pay forOverall I have become a reluctant Apple convert. It's easy to see why they have become market leader with such an excellent product. Of course in another 2 or 3 years the tech will have moved on again, there may be a new market-leading manufacturer and the 5s will be an antique. But until then, the 5s for me is the King of cellphones.Finally, a lot of one-star reviews posted on amazon are from buyers griping about having been shipped locked phones by online sellers. This must be very frustrating but these are not really product reviews, they are complaints about the seller. The solution is easy: buy from an Apple store and they'll set up the new iPhone for you and transfer all the data from your old phone.
title: Apple iPhone 5s, Space Gray 16GB (Unlocked)

reviewText: ProsTouch ID works perfectlyExcellent performanceGreat all-round cameraVery light and comfortable in one handConsBattery life could be better4-inch screen too small for someExtra storage costKey Features: 4-inch Retina display; Fingerprint unlocking; 8MP Camera; True-Tone LED flash; A7 Dual-core processor; Aluminium bodyOn a day to day basis the iPhone 5S does everything I want it to do, and does the things I do most, better than any other phone I’ve used. It’s not gimmicky and other than the lack of widgets and customisations there’s not much I miss from using bigger Android phones. If, as expected, Apple does up the screen size in the iPhone 6 I’ll be interested to see whether I’ll enjoy the experience quite as much.
title: Apple iPhone 5s, Space Gray 16GB (Unlocked)
